awd_titl_txt: The Nanomechanical and Viscoelastic Responses of Ultrathin Polymer Films
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The technological infrastructure that provides science and engineering solutions to the rapidly growing nanotechnology area is of considerable national interest.  The present work addresses fundamentals of the nanoconfinement behavior of materials that form the basis of the relevant enabling technologies. One important set of problems addressed relates to the engineering properties (such as stiffness and yield strength) of nanometer-thick films that are in freely standing form and, consequently, cannot be readily measured. The only method available for making such measurements in such materials is a bubble-inflation method developed in the PI's laboratory that allows testing of extremely small quantities of material, especially nanometer-thin polymer films. The work investigates the engineering properties of freely standing polymer films deep in the glassy state with particular emphasis on yield behavior. These studies will be the first to provide film thickness and temperature dependence of yield in freely standing films. Also, in the freely standing films, a large enhancement in the material stiffness is observed and, recently, conflicting theoretical models of the stiffening behavior have appeared to explain the phenomenon.  Such predictions are, of course important to nanomaterial design and use, and the present work will establish the range of validity of these theories. Molecular architecture effects will also be investigated. Finally, the nanobubble inflation experiment permits investigations of novel materials that were previously unachievable due to their extremely small quantities. In this case, the investigators will study ultrastable polymer glasses made by physical vapor deposition (PVD) and that can be made more stable than even a 20 million year old amber glass. This high stability allows the interrogation of a long-standing question whose resolution is fundamental to theories of glasses and, in particular, how to make long-term predictions of their behavior in applications to important areas such as advanced composites and adhesives.  



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The behavior of ultrathin polymer films remains an intense area of investigation, but most studies have been limited to the case of substrate-supported films even though studies suggest much larger effects occur in the freely standing state. The present work tests three aspects of freely standing ultrathin films using the TTU bubble inflation method and takes advantage of the method's capability of making viscoelastic measurements on extremely small quantities of material to study the response of an ultrastable polymer glass made by physical vapor deposition (PVD). One important set of problems addressed relates to the engineering properties, such as modulus and yield strength of nanometer thick films that are in freely standing form and, consequently, not readily measured. The only method available for making such measurements in such materials is a bubble inflation method that allows testing of extremely small quantities of material, especially ultrathin or nano-metric polymer films. The work investigates the engineering properties of freely standing polymer films deep in the glassy state with particular emphasis on yield behavior. Also, in freely standing films, a large modulus enhancement is observed and, recently, conflicting theoretical models of the stiffening behavior have appeared to explain the phenomenon.  Such predictions are, of course important to nanomaterial design and use and the present work will establish the range of validity of these theories.  Branched polymers have been shown to exhibit different nanoscale behavior from linear counterparts upon confinement on a supporting layer and the TTU bubble inflation method will be used to examine the effects of branching and unentangled polymer chain length on the viscoelastic properties of freely standing ultrathin films. Finally, it remains controversial whether or not the dynamics (relaxation time or viscosity) in glass-forming liquids, including polymers, diverge at a finite temperature. The PI's group has now demonstrated the first PVD ultrastable polymer glass that can be used to determine the upper bound relaxation times in a fashion similar to prior work with a 20 million year old amber but over a larger "window" of temperatures because the PVD polymer has a fictive temperature at least 50 K below the glass transition temperature, and optimization of the PVD conditions offers the possibility of an even larger testing window. Should the experiment be successful, it will provide further experimental data that can challenge theories of the behavior of glass-forming systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
One of the major challenges in the condensed matter sciences is the development of models that fully describe glass-formation and the glass transition temperature Tg behavior of complex liquids.  The full understanding is important to both processing at temperatures above the Tg and to performance (such as lifetime and dimensional stability) below the Tg.  There is much emphasis in the community that the equilibrium viscosity can be described by the so-called Vogel, Fulcher, Tammann (VFT) or the Williams, Landel, Ferry (WLF) that describe the data over a fairly broad range of viscosities, but both extrapolate to an infinite viscosity at a finite temperature at approximately 50 to 100 Kelvin below the Tg. This temperature is often referred to as TVFT In addition, in many systems the entropy is also seen to extrapolate to a similar temperature now known as the Kauzmann temperature TK.  The connection between the two has led to the development of theoretical frameworks that are based on the idea of an "ideal" glass transition at TK or TVFT.  Determining how the equilibrium behavior actually extrapolates to below the Tg is difficult because the relaxation times or viscosities become extremely large even if the response is not diverging, thus it is necessary to develop means of "finessing" the problem. 

In the body of work supported by the present project, we developed two different methods to finesse the problem.  This depends on the idea of a fictive temperature Tf that relates to the frozen-in structure of the glass when it is formed from the equilibrium state. The definition of Tf is shown in Figure 1 and there we see that when T>Tf the volume of the sample is lower than in the (extrapolated) equilibrium state.  When this is true, we then know from prior work that the high density system exhibits a longer relaxation time than does the low density system.  Thus, if the relaxation time can be determined in the condition of T>Tf, one has an estimate of the temperature dependence of the relaxation time (or viscosity) that is an upper-bound (greater than) the equilibrium relaxation time. Thus, the extrapolated VFT or WLF relaxation times should be exceeded should such models be valid representations of the temperature dependence of the dynamics of the glass-forming fluid.  We have succeeded in finding glasses formed millions of years ago (ancient ambers) that meet this requirement and we developed a vapor deposition method for perfluoropolymers that leads to extremely stable glasses. In both cases we found fictive temperatures very far below the Tg and were able to make measurements of the so-called scaled relaxation time by using time-temperature-superposition principles to determine the response over the temperature range from Tf to Tg.  The first work was with an amber material that had a fictive temperature 43.6 K below the Tg and the results are shown in Figure 2 where we see a very large deviation of the relaxation time from the VFT extrapolation from equilibrium data above the Tg. While the Tf of this material was still above the TVFT by 27.2 K. Thus the data challenge the VFT extrapolation, but still leave a question about the possible divergence of time-scales near to the TVFT or TK. 

This question was partially answered with work on a vapor deposited perfluoropolymer that was found to calorimetrically exhibit a fictive temperature Tf=346 K as much as 57 K below the Tg, which was very close to the TVFT=346 K. The scaled relaxation times for the system with a slightly lower fictive temperature reduction of 55 K, i.e., within 2 K of the TVFT. The results are shown in Figures 3 and 4 where we see that the temperature dependence of the logarithm of the relaxation times varies either linearly in temperature or reciprocal temperature to within 2 K of the TVFT.

During the work we also discovered two systems for which the Tf is lower than the TVFT. In one instance it was through vapor deposition of a different perfluoropolymer. The polymer had a TVFT of 297.2 K and Tf= 269.5 K by a novel atomic force microscopy dilatometric method that we developed in the project. The other system was a 50 million-year-old amber from Fushun China that had a Tf 193 K lower than the Tg and though the TVFT of this system was not measured, polymers such as amber have TVFT from 50 to 100 K below the Tg.

The range of results challenges all theories of the glass transition that demand diverging time-scales as well as those based on the thermodynamic conundrum nominally posited by the Kauzmann paradox.  Ultimately, this work also shows that the methods developed give novel means to study the "deep glassy state".


Last Modified: 07/26/2024
Modified by: Gregory B Mckenna

  • Figure 3. Log relaxation time vs. T for a VPD perfluoropolymer showing that between the fictive temperature (approximately equal to the VFT temperature) the upper bound relaxation times deviate strongly from the VFT extrapolation. Data reported by Yoon and McKenna, Science Advances 2018.
    Gregory B. McKenna
    Public Domain
    Gregory B Mckenna
    Log relaxation time vs T-PVD amorphous perfluoropolymer
por.por_txt_cntn:
One of the major challenges in the condensed matter sciences is the development of models that fully describe glass-formation and the glass transition temperature Tg behavior of complex liquids. The full understanding is important to both processing at temperatures above the Tg and to performance (such as lifetime and dimensional stability) below the Tg. There is much emphasis in the community that the equilibrium viscosity can be described by the so-called Vogel, Fulcher, Tammann (VFT) or the Williams, Landel, Ferry (WLF) that describe the data over a fairly broad range of viscosities, but both extrapolate to an infinite viscosity at a finite temperature at approximately 50 to 100 Kelvin below the Tg. This temperature is often referred to as TVFT In addition, in many systems the entropy is also seen to extrapolate to a similar temperature now known as the Kauzmann temperature TK. The connection between the two has led to the development of theoretical frameworks that are based on the idea of an "ideal" glass transition at TK or TVFT. Determining how the equilibrium behavior actually extrapolates to below the Tg is difficult because the relaxation times or viscosities become extremely large even if the response is not diverging, thus it is necessary to develop means of "finessing" the problem.


In the body of work supported by the present project, we developed two different methods to finesse the problem. This depends on the idea of a fictive temperature Tf that relates to the frozen-in structure of the glass when it is formed from the equilibrium state. The definition of Tf is shown in Figure 1 and there we see that when TTf the volume of the sample is lower than in the (extrapolated) equilibrium state. When this is true, we then know from prior work that the high density system exhibits a longer relaxation time than does the low density system. Thus, if the relaxation time can be determined in the condition of TTf, one has an estimate of the temperature dependence of the relaxation time (or viscosity) that is an upper-bound (greater than) the equilibrium relaxation time. Thus, the extrapolated VFT or WLF relaxation times should be exceeded should such models be valid representations of the temperature dependence of the dynamics of the glass-forming fluid. We have succeeded in finding glasses formed millions of years ago (ancient ambers) that meet this requirement and we developed a vapor deposition method for perfluoropolymers that leads to extremely stable glasses. In both cases we found fictive temperatures very far below the Tg and were able to make measurements of the so-called scaled relaxation time by using time-temperature-superposition principles to determine the response over the temperature range from Tf to Tg. The first work was with an amber material that had a fictive temperature 43.6 K below the Tg and the results are shown in Figure 2 where we see a very large deviation of the relaxation time from the VFT extrapolation from equilibrium data above the Tg. While the Tf of this material was still above the TVFT by 27.2 K. Thus the data challenge the VFT extrapolation, but still leave a question about the possible divergence of time-scales near to the TVFT or TK.


This question was partially answered with work on a vapor deposited perfluoropolymer that was found to calorimetrically exhibit a fictive temperature Tf=346 K as much as 57 K below the Tg, which was very close to the TVFT=346 K. The scaled relaxation times for the system with a slightly lower fictive temperature reduction of 55 K, i.e., within 2 K of the TVFT. The results are shown in Figures 3 and 4 where we see that the temperature dependence of the logarithm of the relaxation times varies either linearly in temperature or reciprocal temperature to within 2 K of the TVFT.


During the work we also discovered two systems for which the Tf is lower than the TVFT. In one instance it was through vapor deposition of a different perfluoropolymer. The polymer had a TVFT of 297.2 K and Tf= 269.5 K by a novel atomic force microscopy dilatometric method that we developed in the project. The other system was a 50 million-year-old amber from Fushun China that had a Tf 193 K lower than the Tg and though the TVFT of this system was not measured, polymers such as amber have TVFT from 50 to 100 K below the Tg.


The range of results challenges all theories of the glass transition that demand diverging time-scales as well as those based on the thermodynamic conundrum nominally posited by the Kauzmann paradox. Ultimately, this work also shows that the methods developed give novel means to study the "deep glassy state".					Last Modified: 07/26/2024
